meanings.definition: To attract or pull towards oneself
meanings.sent1: The strong magnetising force pulled the metal objects closer.
meanings.sent2: The magnetising power of the magnet drew the paperclips to it.
meanings.sent3: The magnetising effect of the fridge magnet made it the center of attention.
meanings.sent4: Her charisma was like a magnetising field, drawing people in effortlessly.
meanings.sent5: The magician's performance was so magnetising that the audience couldn't look away.

meanings.sent1: By magnetising the metal rod, it became attracted to magnets.
meanings.sent2: The scientist was magnetising the iron particles to create a magnetic field.
meanings.sent3: The wizard's spell accidentally ended up magnetising all the coins in the room.
meanings.sent4: The magnetic storm was so intense that it felt like nature was magnetising everything around.
meanings.sent5: The superhero's suit was specially designed to be magnetising to repel bullets.

meanings.sent1: The thrilling movie trailer was magnetising, making everyone eager to watch it.
meanings.sent2: The new video game was magnetising players from all over the world.
meanings.sent3: The idea of a treasure hunt was so magnetising that even the lazy cat got excited.
meanings.sent4: Her storytelling was so magnetising that the children sat still, captivated by every word.
meanings.sent5: The aroma of freshly baked cookies was so magnetising that it drew everyone to the kitchen.
